title: Do Wall Street Analysts Like Accenture Stock?
description: Accenture has significantly underperformed the broader market and the tech sector over the past year, and analysts have turned more cautious on the stock’s prospects.
content:
Valued at $149.8 billion by market cap, Dublin, Ireland-based Accenture plc (ACN) is a global leader in professional services. Accenture partners with top businesses, governments, and organizations worldwide to enhance their digital foundations, optimize operations, accelerate revenue growth, and improve public services.

Accenture has significantly underperformed the broader market over the past year. ACN stock has plunged 24.5% over the past 52 weeks and 32.2% on a YTD basis, compared to the S&P 500 Index’s ($SPX) 19.3% gains over the past year and 8.4% returns in 2025.
• Tesla Is Axing Its Dojo Supercomputer Plans. What Does That Mean for TSLA Stock Here?
• Should You Buy the Post-Preliminary Earnings Plunge in C3.ai Stock?
• Stop Missing Market Moves: Get the FREE Barchart Brief – your midday dose of stock movers, trending sectors, and actionable trade ideas, delivered right to your inbox. Sign Up Now!

Narrowing the focus, Accenture has also underperformed the Technology Select Sector SPDR Fund’s (XLK) 28.4% gains over the past year and 13.6% surge in 2025.

Accenture stock has remained under pressure in recent months. Its stock prices dropped 6.9% in a single trading session following the release of its Q3 results on Jun. 20. The company’s topline for the quarter increased by a notable 7.7% year-over-year to $17.7 billion, beating Street estimates by 2.6%. Further, growth in earnings and a drop in outstanding shares due to share buybacks led to an impressive 14.8% growth in EPS to $3.49, surpassing the consensus estimates by 5.8%. Moreover, the company also raised its lower band of full-year revenue growth guidance from the prior range of 5% - 6% to 6% - 7% (in local currency).

However, Accenture’s new bookings at the end of Q3 stood at $19.7 billion, down 6% year-over-year in USD terms and down 7% in local currency. This dented investor confidence and led to a selloff.

For the full fiscal 2025, ending in August, analysts expect ACN to deliver an EPS of $12.88, up 7.8% year-over-year. The company has a mixed earnings surprise history. While it surpassed the Street’s bottom-line estimates thrice over the past four quarters, it missed the projections on one other occasion.

The stock has a consensus “Moderate Buy” rating overall. Of the 23 analysts covering the stock, opinions include 15 “Strong Buys,” one “Moderate Buy,” and seven “Holds.”

This configuration is notably less optimistic than two months ago, when the stock had a consensus “Strong Buy” rating overall, with 16 “Strong Buy” recommendations on it.
summary: Accenture plc (ACN) is a global leader in professional services, valued at $149.8 billion by market cap. The company has significantly underperformed the broader market over the past year, with ACN stock dropping 24.5% over the 52-week period and 32.2% on a YTD basis, compared to the S&P 500 Index's 19.3% gains. Despite a significant increase in Q3 results, Accenture's new bookings at the end of Q3 stood at $19.7 billion, down 6% year-over-year in USD terms and down 7% in local currency. For the full fiscal 2025, analysts expect ACN to deliver an EPS of $12.88, up 7.8% year over-year.
shortSummary: Accenture plc shares dropped 24.5% after Q3 results, with Wall Street analysts less optimistic despite strong earnings growth and increased revenue expectations.

argos_summary: Accenture plc, a leading global professional services firm based in Dublin, has seen its stock decline significantly, dropping 24.5% over the past year and 32.2% year-to-date, contrasting with the S&P 500's gains. Despite a 7.7% year-over-year revenue increase in Q3 and an EPS growth of 14.8%, the company's new bookings fell by 6% year-over-year, leading to a selloff. Analysts maintain a 'Moderate Buy' consensus on the stock, though this sentiment has weakened from a previous 'Strong Buy' rating.
